case: A 54-year-old Black with a history of aortic stenosis and travel to South America presents with subacute progressive dyspnea, intermittent fevers, a cough that produces pink sputum, orthopnea, and unintentional weight loss. They are found to be febrile, hypoxemic, tachypneic, and tachycardic.
differential: Infective Endocarditis with secondary Acute Decompensated Heart Failure
Acute Decompensated Heart Failure (secondary to critical aortic stenosis) with a superimposed infection (e.g., Pneumonia)
Pulmonary Tuberculosis (with or without cardiac involvement)
Chagasic Cardiomyopathy (reactivation or acute on chronic)
Severe Community-Acquired Pneumonia with Sepsis and resultant cardiac decompensation
Malignancy (e.g., Lung Cancer or Lymphoma) with cardiac compromise
Systemic Vasculitis with pulmonary and cardiac involvement (e.g., ANCA-associated vasculitis)

Malignancy (e.g., Lung Cancer or Lymphoma with cardiopulmonary effects)
ANCA-associated Vasculitis with diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
